body: If you want run the rat plugin, use `mvn apache-rat:check`

I think the Oracle needs to set the TLTNODE for the TR before returning the ts.

Oracle doesn't set TLTNODE
1. No Transactors
2. TR gets ts of 10 from Oracle
3. GC gets ts of 15 from Oracle
4. GC check for TLTNODEs
5. TR sets TLTNODE to 10
6. TR starts scanning with ts 10
7. GC starts dropping columns with TS < 15

Oracle sets TLTNODE
1. No Transactors
2. TR requests ts from Oracle which sets 10 as TLNODE for TR and returns 10
3. GC gets ts of 15 from Oracle
4. GC check for TLNODEs and finds TR with 10 and sets min time to 10
5. GC starts dropping columns with ts < 10
The first transaction to execute will get a new timestamp.  Would not use timestamp set on TLTNODE

Ahh.. I see.  If a TR gets a new timestamp after it sets its TLTNODE, the TR will always have a ts greater than the GC.  Below is revised scenario:
1. No Transactors
2. TR gets ts of 10 from Oracle
3. GC gets ts of 15 from Oracle
4. GC check for TLTNODEs
5. TR sets TLTNODE to 10
6. TR gets ts of 21 from Oracle and uses it for transaction
7. GC starts dropping columns with TS < 15

Some notes that might help during code review:
- The fluo-accumulo module depends on fluo-api.  This is due to a dependency on the fluo-api data types in LockValue and a few other classes.  With some refactoring, I can remove this dependency but this dependency might not be a bad thing and may be unavoidable eventually.
- I needed to move the constants in ColumnUtil to a new class called ColumnConstants in the accumulo module.  An alternative name could be AccumuloConstants.  Let me know if you have an opinion on this.
I like ColumnConstants
This issue was fixed with #121.  All properties are now in fluo.properties file.

We do have <developers> tags in the pom currently- which is required by Sonatype OSS in order to stage releases (they run through a series of checks for correct signature, valid parent pom, valid CRCs, etc...). 

That being said- I didn't think about it before but we have 2 places with Authors and right now the only authors are collaborators. IMO, it doesn't matter much currently but if we suddenly find ourselves supporting a growing community and making updates often then I think we should opt for removing the AUTHORS file.

I'm thinking of starting with an algorithm that will allow us to dump some N number of entries into a Fluo table and then adjusting the percentage of the store to update through transactions. We should try to mimick a map/reduce process over the same data table (not using Fluo's API) to allow for the same functionality. I'd like to run the tests over several different percentage combinations and find the sweet spot. Hopefully, optimal crawl rate ratio will be similar (or better) than Percolator's (0%-40% is optimal for Fluo. >40% being optimal for Map/reduce). We should at least be able benchmark and 

1) post our results
2) determine the impact of large design changes
Looking at Guava some more, it also has Collections2.transform() method.  So the transformation for rows in example above can already be done w/o any changes to API.

Requiring the classpath setting is strange for Mini and the case where an admin operation besides init is performed.  I am thinking it should default to empty string, and its not set then the class path context should not be setup in Accumulo.
Were you thinking of removing the actual object ColumnVisibility and replacing it with  our own object or just using strings for visibilities and removing ColumnVisibility altogether?
Same with qual() vs cq() and vis() vs. cv()
Does anyone have a specific preference? I tend to side on the fam() vis() and qual() names

I hadn't thought it about what to replace it with too much.  Maybe Strings would be good, with the caveat that we validate (and keep a LRU cache of successfully validated vis strings).  Doing the validation w/ a cache behind the scenes would probably be better than expecting the user to try to reuse col vis object themsleves to avoid parsing.
yeah, I like fam(), qual(), and vis() too.
+1 to using Strings.  I think it will make the API simpler.
fam(), qual(), & vis() are cool with me

100 chars, may be nice for github.  However on a nice wide monitor (w/ Eclipse, vim, gitlab, etc), 160 lines is nice.  This the reason we went w/ 160 for Accumulo.  We felt going w/ less was a waste of space.

Besides viewing code on github, are there other reasons to go w/ 100?

I prefer shorter because it's easier to view code side by side or on a phone.  While comments look good at 160, I think code at 160 can be harder to read.  However, I didn't realize 160 was chosen for a reason.  I am cool with keeping it at 160 if I am the only one who prefers shorter.  We can let this issue stew until we have consensus...

I started working on #151, but I think this issue is a pre-req for that.  So I am going to do it first.

During the rebase with master, I had to create MockSnapshot and MockSnapshotBase as MockTransaction cannot be cast into Snapshot anymore.  Also, the rebase of TypedSnapshot & TypedSnapshotBase was complicated.  These could be reviewed before this pull request is merged.

I looked at this for awhile. The exception is caused in a background thread of curator so this is tricky to debug.  The exception might just be thrown due to timing issues in the setup/teardown of integration tests.

@keith-turner are you cool if I squash?

If you enable the `Potential resource leak` warning in Eclipse, a warning will show if a Closeable object created by a Factory is not closed.  I am going to add this to our coding standards.  I also created #190 to fix all of these warnings in Fluo after it is enabled.  I am going close this issue as enabling the `Potential resource leak` warning solves this issue.
This issue can be closed given the completion of #94 #98 #97 #122
I am not sure this is a good idea, closing for now.

I started looking at adding String to Snapshot and Transaction and became disillusioned and started working on improving the TypeLayer instead.

Transaction currently has the following method.

``` java
public void set(Bytes row, Column col, Bytes value)
```

We could add something like the following.

``` java
public void set(String row, Column col, String value)
```

However a common use case will be that I have a binary value and a String row or visa versa.  So we could also add the following methods.

``` java
public void set(String row, Column col, Bytes value)
public void set(Bytes row, Column col, String value)
```

Now this is just for this one set method.   What about the other get and set methods?  Thats why I stopped working on this and started working on #153.  The TypeLayer can easily handle the combinations of types w/o a large number of overloaded methods.  I am not sure if I want to do anything for this issue for Snapshot and Transaction.  Need to look at other places in API.

If you ever want to revisit this, I've found that accepting Iterables as method arguments works well, but you want to avoid returning an Iterable from a method. Seems to make sense with what Guava is doing as well.

> If you ever want to revisit this, I've found that accepting Iterables

Do you think this is something that should be done?  Switching from Set to Iterable is what made me decide against this.

> you want to avoid returning an Iterable from a method

why?
I noticed some suppresions where at the method level.  What are your thoughts on the possibility of future resource leaks introduced in the method being suppressed?

> Do you think this is something that should be done? Switching from Set to Iterable is what made me decide against this.

Honestly, I haven't really looked at the API's close enough to make the judgement call. I just saw the subject and wanted to mention it.

My opinions on it are based on the following. For method arguments, typically the method doesn't actually care what the data structure implementation is. If you're just treating it as a stream of entries/records coming in, you don't need to impose anything special like a list or a set. If your method needs or benefits from having some certain data structure, then that's a good reason to use a Set or List specifically.

For returning Iterables, it's the same premise in reverse. If you consider what a caller might be doing with the result from your method, you want to be as specific as possible. If you only return Iterable, the caller will have to manipulate that data structure to get to some List, Set, or otherwise. It can also introduce some confusion because users don't really know what the method is returning to them (is it a big data structure, is it expensive to make, etc). Returning as specific of a type from a method as possible is a good idea as the caller can always downcast it to something more generic that fits their circumstances.

Take it with a grain of salt. This is my current opinion :)

Thanks @joshelser, makes perfect sense.   

The reason I wanted to stick w/ Set in the API for columns is that we really don't expect a user to pass a List with the same column repeated 20 times.  However, I suppose this reasoning is inconsistent.  For getting rows, we really do expect a unique set of rows.

That could be a problem but there are only a few method-level suppression.  We'll just need to be careful.  I tried to put the suppressions at the local variable level but Eclipse wouldn't always let me.
nice descriptions
Not having the suppression would probably lead to all warning being ignored, so its probably a necessary evil.  We'll just have to be carful when modifying methods w/ suppression like you said.

The question of whether or not close methods should be idempotent (can be called multiple times) came up in #190.  @keith-turner and I came to the conclusion that user facing close methods in the API should be able to be called multiple times while close methods in implementation code should only be called once.  A second call to close() is a sign that there may a bug.  In implementation code, preconditions should be used to check if the close() is called multiple times and throw an exception.

Off the top of my head, I think of two reasonable ways we can handle this. I'm leaning towards the second.

1) One solution could be to simply fail if a table with the specified name already exists. But then you'd wonder if the user intended to multi-purpose a table. Should we force exclusive creation of the table?

2) It's possible there's a table in the cluster with the same name as the proposed Fluo table in the config but not intended for the same purpose. I think we should, for an alpha release, just do nothing but add a warning "WARN: A table with the specified name already exists in the cluster. Fluo may have unexpected results". This would allow them to act but doesn't stand in the way.

In a 1.0.0, I'd like to give the user an option: "A table with the specified name already exists, would you like to [d]rop, [r]ename, or [a]bort?"

I'm also pondering whether or not we should use namespaces for our tables so that we can, at the very least, guarantee the intention was to drop a Fluo table.

The more I think about it- it would be better to fail because we need to make certain guarantees about the table (like no versioning iterator) without changing the configurations of the table and confusing the user.

After reading through @cjnolet's comments in #14, I think the best solution is to remove the `io.fluo.admin.zookeeper.clear` property and prompt the user when the `initialize.sh` script is run.  It could go something like below: 
- User runs configures fluo.properties and runs `./initialize.sh``
- Initialization first checks if instance exists.  If it does, prompts user with:

```
A Fluo instance exists in zookeeper at /fluo. Do you want re-initialize?  Y / N
```

If No chosen, abort.  Next, if table chosen by user in fluo.properties exists, prompt user with:

```
An Accumulo table called 'mytable' already exists.  Do you want to drop and recreate this table?  Y / N
(If No chosen, pick a new table name in fluo.properties and re-run intialize.sh). 
```

Finally, initialize Zookeeper and create table after getting through above.

There could also be an `initalize.sh --force` that answers yes to both questions above for scripts.

In FluoAdmin, initalize() could be modified to the following:

``` java
initialize(boolean clearZk, boolean clearTable) throws AlreadyInitalizedException, TableExistsException
```

@cjnolet, while I think this would be great to have for alpha, an issue could be created and this could be done in Beta. If this is pushed to Beta, I think an intermediate solution is to check if the table exists before any zookeeper initialization and print a message (rather than throwing an exception) telling the user that they need to drop the accumulo table before initializing this instance.

@mikewalch, Your solution is right along the lines of what I was thinking in the ticket. I think that'd be great for a beta instance. I was also thinking about it more last night after my comments- the clearZookeepers() would be misleading if we were expecting that to act upon the table as well so I agree that should either be removed or renamed. IMO, it could probably be removed in light of better user-interaction in the script itself (see Accumulo's Initialize class).

In the meantime, I do agree that a better message should be printed before the clearing of zookeeper if the table already exists. I'm thinking maybe we could change "clearZookeeper()" to "allowReinitialize()" (something that would let a user know they'd be starting from scratch.) 

I'm okay with this simply because I'm seeing the alpha release more as an opportunity for users to play with and begin to build Fluo into the designs for their own applications. As a result, I think we can get away with changing the property and the underlying logic in beta.

What do you think?
Created #198 for further discussion
One thing to take into consideration is that we probably don't want to even bother re-initializing the table if the user says NO to reinitializing Zookeeper.

It looks like there are two intermediate options:
1. Keep `io.fluo.admin.zookeeper.clear` which will only clear zookeeper.  Always abort if table exists (before clearing or initializing zookeeper) and print out a message.
2. Rename to `io.fluo.admin.zookeeper.clear` to `io.fluo.admin.allow.reinitialize` or `io.fluo.admin.instance.clear` which will now clear zookeeper and table if property is set to true.

I am fine with either option as it should only be temporary until #198
+1 I like this approach- I don't like forcing too much on a user and causing annoyances that could be avoided with a little smarter API.
This ticket should be done after #198
Implemented fixes based on feedback.

#33 is a possible solution to this

AFAIK M/R has no mechanism for the input format to clean up after the entire job is completed.  The solution for this issue should avoid an issue like [ACCUMULO-829](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ACCUMULO-826), where killing the process that started the M/R job borks the entire job.   

Thats why I think #33 may be a good solution.  A user could do something like the following.
1. create named snapshot
2. run job against named snapshot
3. delete named snapshot  

It should be easy for a user to do the above steps in a single process, but we should not require that it be done in a single process.   I think #33 will be fairly easy to implement now that #8 is done.

It sounds like the easiest to use approach might be something in the middle.
1. Automatically created a snapshot (named, or otherwise) in `InputFormat.getSplits` and make w/e necessary advertisement to ensure that snapshot isn't deleted. You don't try to solve any automatic cleanup.
2. Provide some sort of API in which users can call to instrument their Tool to create a snapshot, pass that snapshot into the `Configuration` for the InputFormat to use (instead of making a new snapshot) and then let the Tool clean up after the job finishes (assuming that the process that's running the Tool is still alive).

Long term, you can then try to think about something more fancy that can ensure snapshots aren't leaked.
@ericnewton, can this be closed?  your commit didn't close it.
closed with 36d385f

@joshelser I was thinking of only providing option 2 that you described.   The user would be required to pass a named snapshot to FluoInputFormat.   For Option 1 it seems like it would leave a snapshot around forever that would prevent GC?

Sorry, I thought you meant option 1 as the default where they could come back "later" and clean it up -- e.g. some CLI tool. I guess if the Tool dies, it would be nice to provide some way that doesn't force the user to write some 5 line java class to clean up the snapshot and let GC happen again.
